questions.text: Fick's law of diffusion is dependent on all except

options.label: C
options.text: The molecular weight of the gas

questions.correct_answer: D. The posture of the subject
questions.explanation: Ans. D) The posture of the subject

questions.text: An old man of 43 year of age presents with peripheral edema. Which tracer his doctor should choose to know his interstitial fluid volume?
questions.correct_answer: A. Mannitol and Evan’s blue dye
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Mannitol and Evan’s blue dye

questions.text: Which one of the following membrane has highest content of protein content per gram of tissue
Which of the following transport mechanism does not require ATP:
Gap junctions are intercellular connections that

options.label: A
options.text: Primarily serve to keep cells separated and allow for transport across a tissue barrier.

options.label: B
options.text: Serve as a regulated cytoplasmic bridge for sharing of small molecules between cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Serve as a barrier to prevent protein movement within the cellular membrane.

options.label: D
options.text: Are cellular components for constitutive exocytosis that occurs between adjacent cells.

questions.correct_answer: B. Serve as a regulated cytoplasmic bridge for sharing of small molecules between cells.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Serve as a regulated cytoplasmic bridge for sharing of small molecules between cells.

questions.text: F-actin is a component of the cellular cytoskeleton that

options.label: A
options.text: Provides a structural component for cell movement.

options.label: B
options.text: Is defined as the “functional” form of actin in the cell.

options.label: C
options.text: Refers to the actin subunits that provide the molecular building blocks of the extended actin molecules found in the cell.

options.label: D
options.text: Provide the molecular architecture for cell-to-cell communication.

questions.correct_answer: A. Provides a structural component for cell movement.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Provides a structural component for cell movement.

questions.text: In a volunteer, 10 grams of mannitol was injected into the venous blood. At equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was measured at 60 mg/dl. Calculate the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume based on this information.
The force of muscle contraction can be increased by all except:

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the frequency of activation of motor units.

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the number of motor units activated.

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the strength of stimuli from maximal to supramaximal.

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing the resting length of the muscle.

questions.correct_answer: C. Increasing the strength of stimuli from maximal to supramaximal.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Increasing the strength of stimuli from maximal to supramaximal.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with a suspected gastrointestinal motility disorder, an endoscopic biopsy reveals alterations of Dense bodies in smooth muscle tissue. Which structural feature found at a specific site within smooth muscle cells is associated with the attachment of actin filaments and contributes to the contractile function.This altered structure is analogous to which structure found in skeletal muscle?

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: A band, I Band, Z line, H zone

questions.correct_answer: A. Z line, A band, H zone, I Band
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Z line, A band, H zone, I Band

questions.text: Which of the following physiological processes is not correctly paired with a structure? Electrical transmission: gap junction Negative feedback inhibition: Renshaw cell Synaptic vesicle docking and fusion: presynaptic nerve terminal End plate potential: muscarinic cholinergic receptor Action potential generation: initial segment

Which of the following electrophysiological events is correctly paired with thechange in ionic currents causing the event?

options.label: A
options.text: Fast inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSPs) and closing of Cl − channels.

options.label: B
options.text: End plate potential and an increase in Na+ conductance.

options.label: C
options.text: Presynaptic inhibition and closure of voltage-gated K + channels.

options.label: D
options.text: Slow EPSPs and an increase in K+ conductance.

questions.correct_answer: B. End plate potential and an increase in Na+ conductance.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) End plate potential and an increase in Na+ conductance.

questions.text: A motorcyclist suffered head injury 6 months back and presents with persistent memory deficits following injury. Choose the most appropriately matched option related to memory?
questions.correct_answer: C. Medial temporal lobe- Declarative memory
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Medial Temporal lobe - Declarative memory

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman sees her physician to report muscle weakness in the extraocular eye muscles and muscles of the extremities. She states that she feels fine when she gets up in the morning, but the weakness begins soon after she becomes active. The weakness is improved by rest. Sensation appears normal. The physician treats her with an anticholinesterase inhibitor, and she notes immediate return of muscle strength. Her physician diagnoses her with
The phenomenon shown in the picture here can be best described as:
All the following are properties of ventricular muscle fibers: All or none law Length tension relation Tetanus Long refractory period

In a 42-year-old male, during the clinical examination, his blood pressure was found to be 132/82 mm Hg, heart rate was 70/min and respiratory rate was 18/min. What would be the stroke volume in this patient, if his cardiac output was 4.9 L?
All of the following statements about the flow of blood in a blood vessel are true, except:

options.label: A
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference

options.label: B
options.text: The blood flow will be directly proportional to the radius

options.label: C
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the length

options.label: D
options.text: The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the viscosity

questions.correct_answer: A. The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference
questions.explanation: Ans. A) The blood flow will be inversely proportional to the pressure difference

questions.text: Currents caused by opening of which of the following channels contribute to the repolarization phase of the action potential of ventricular muscle fibers?

A 60-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70 beats per minute, arterial pressure of 130/85 mm Hg, and normal body temperature. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is shown below. Based on the diagram, what is her cardiac output in milliliters per minute and When does
Starling’s law of the heart

options.label: B
options.text: Explains the increase in heart rate produced by exercise.

options.label: C
options.text: Explains the increase in cardiac output that occurs when venous return is increased.

options.label: D
options.text: Explains the increase in cardiac output when the sympathetic nerves supplying the heart are stimulated.

questions.correct_answer: C. Explains the increase in cardiac output that occurs when venous return is increased.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Explains the increase in cardiac output that occurs when venous return is increased.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the cardiovascular regulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Baroreceptors get activated in hypotension and help increase Blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Baroreceptors inhibit the nucleus ambiguous which inhibits the sympathetic system

options.label: C
options.text: Nucleus tractus solitarius activates vagal centres

options.label: D
options.text: Vagus nerve carries afferent fibres from carotid sinus baroreceptors

questions.correct_answer: C. Nucleus tractus solitarius activates vagal centres
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Nucleus tractus solitarius activates vagal centres

questions.text: The velocity of blood flow

options.label: A
options.text: Is higher in the capillaries than the arterioles.

options.label: B
options.text: Is higher in the veins than in the venules.

options.label: C
options.text: Is higher in the veins than the arteries.

options.label: D
options.text: Is reduced in a constricted area of a blood vessel.

questions.correct_answer: B. Is higher in the veins than in the venules.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Is higher in the veins than in the venules.

questions.text: Which characteristic physiological response pattern is associated with a pulmonary reflex mechanism stimulated by the activation of pulmonary J-receptors, specifically related to the release of inflammatory mediators or pulmonary congestion in conditions such as pulmonary edema or interstitial lung disease?
In regional ventilation and perfusion of the lung, which of the following is correct

options.label: A
options.text: Upper regions of the lung ventilate better than the lower regions

options.label: B
options.text: When supine the apical and basal ventilation is equal

options.label: C
options.text: V/Q ratio increases down the lung

options.label: D
options.text: The highest alveolar PO 2 , is at the base of the lung.

questions.correct_answer: B. When supine the apical and basal ventilation is equal
questions.explanation: Ans. B) When supine the apical and basal ventilation is equal

questions.text: Which one of the following curve shows oxygen Hb dissociation after transfusion of stored blood
The forced vital capacity is

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of air that normally moves into (or out of) the lung with each respiration.

options.label: B
options.text: The amount of air that enters the lung but does not participate in gas exchange.

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of air expired after maximal expiratory effort.

options.label: D
options.text: The largest amount of gas that can be moved into and out of the lungs in 1 min.

questions.correct_answer: C. The amount of air expired after maximal expiratory effort.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) The amount of air expired after maximal expiratory effort.

questions.text: Oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve of a patient shifted from ‘A’ to ‘B’. this can be due to:
Airway resistance

options.label: A
options.text: Is increased if the lungs are removed and inflated with saline.

options.label: B
options.text: Does not affect the work of breathing.

options.label: C
options.text: Is increased in following bronchial smooth muscle contraction.

options.label: D
options.text: Makes up 80% of the work of breathing.

questions.correct_answer: C. Is increased in following bronchial smooth muscle contraction.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Is increased in following bronchial smooth muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during forceful expiration during exercise?

Which of the following has the greatest effect on the ability of blood to transport oxygen?

options.label: A
options.text: Capacity of the blood to dissolve oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Amount of hemoglobin in the blood

options.text: CO 2 content of red blood cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Amount of hemoglobin in the blood
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Amount of hemoglobin in the blood

questions.text: The volume–pressure curves shown in the next diagram were obtained from a young, healthy subject and a patient. Which of the following best describes the condition of the patient?

A 35-year-old man visits his doctor because his wife has long complained of his snoring. He undergoes polysomnography and ventilatory response testing to ascertain the extent and cause of his sleep apnea. The activity of the central chemoreceptors is stimulated by which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in the metabolic rate of the surrounding brain tissue

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in the PO2 of blood flowing through the brain

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in the PCO2 of blood flowing through the brain

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in the pH of the CSF

questions.correct_answer: C. An increase in the PCO2 of blood flowing through the brain
questions.explanation: Ans. C) An increase in the PCO2 of blood flowing through the brain

questions.text: A 32 year old man met with a bike accident and handle of bike hit him badly that when he was brought to the hospital. Doctors find out that there is puncture in parietal pleura membrane. True about this condition is-

options.label: A
options.text: Unopposed inward recoil will be there.

options.label: B
options.text: Intra thorax pressure will be zero

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B are true.

questions.correct_answer: D. Both A and B are true.
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Both A and B are true.

questions.text: A patient with parathyroid deficiency 10 days after inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery would probably have

options.label: A
options.text: Low plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and tetanus.

options.label: B
options.text: Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability and spasm of the muscles.

options.label: C
options.text: High plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.correct_answer: B. Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability and spasm of the muscles.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability and spasm of the muscles (Trousseau sign)

questions.text: In a respiratory clinic, a 45-year-old non-smoker presents with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea and a nonproductive cough. Given the patient's symptoms and the flow-volume loop findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

The clinician evaluates the patient's neurological function, focusing on structures crucial for memory conversion. In a patient with difficulty in storage of long-term memories after conversion from short term memories, which brain structure plays a crucial role in this process?
For the eye to adapt to intense light, which of the following may occur?

options.label: A
options.text: Bipolar cells will continuously transmit signals at the maximum rate possible

options.label: B
options.text: Photochemical in both rods and cones will be reduced to retinal and opsins

options.label: C
options.text: There will be an increase in the size of the pupil

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin A will convert into retinal

questions.correct_answer: B. Photochemical in both rods and cones will be reduced to retinal and opsins
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Photochemical in both rods and cones will be reduced to retinal and opsins

questions.text: There is an area in the dominant hemisphere, which when damaged, might leave the sense of hearing intact but not allow words to be arranged into a comprehensive thought. Which of the following terms is used to identify this portion of the cortex?

options.label: B
options.text: Threshold, Receptive Field, Adaptation, And Discrimination

questions.correct_answer: A. Modality, Location, Intensity, And Duration
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Modality, Location, Intensity, And Duration

questions.text: A 40-year-old man loses his right hand in a farm accident. Four years later, he has episodes of severe pain in the missing hand (phantom limb pain). A detailed PET scan study of his cerebral cortex might be expected to show

options.label: A
options.text: Expansion of the right hand area in his right primary somatosensory cortex.

options.label: B
options.text: A metabolically inactive spot where his hand area in his left primary somatosensory cortex would normally be.

options.label: C
options.text: Projection of fibers from neighboring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his right primary somatosensory cortex.

options.label: D
options.text: Projection of fibers from neighboring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his left primary somatosensory cortex.

questions.correct_answer: D. Projection of fibers from neighboring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his left primary somatosensory cortex.
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Projection of fibers from neighboring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his left primary somatosensory cortex.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male spent the evening in a sleep clinic to determine whether he had obstructive sleep apnea. The tests showed that NREM sleep accounted for over 30% of his total sleep time. Which of the following pattern of changes in central neurotransmitters or neuromodulators are associated with the transition from NREM to wakefulness?

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in norepinephrine, increase in serotonin, increase in acetylcholine, decrease in histamine, and increase in GABA.

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in norepinephrine, decrease in serotonin, increase in acetylcholine, increase in histamine, and increase in GABA.

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in norepinephrine, increase in serotonin, decrease in acetylcholine, increase in histamine, and decrease in GABA.

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in norepinephrine, decrease in serotonin, decrease in acetylcholine, increase in histamine, and decrease in GABA.

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase in norepinephrine, increase in serotonin, decrease in acetylcholine, increase in histamine, and decrease in GABA.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Increase in norepinephrine, increase in serotonin, decrease in acetylcholine, increase in histamine, and decrease in GABA.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely not involved in production of LTP?
Thirst is stimulated by

options.label: A
options.text: Increases in plasma osmolality and volume.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in plasma osmolality and a decrease in plasma volume.

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in plasma osmolality and an increase in plasma volume.

options.label: D
options.text: Injection of vasopressin into the hypothalamus.

questions.correct_answer: B. An increase in plasma osmolality and a decrease in plasma volume.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) An increase in plasma osmolality and a decrease in plasma volume.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect about vasopressin?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a more powerful vasoconstrictor than angiotensin II.

options.label: B
options.text: Concentration of circulating blood vasopressin after severe hemorrhage can increase enough to attenuate reductions in arterial pressure markedly.

options.label: D
options.text: Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus

questions.correct_answer: D. Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus.

Which one of the following statement accurately describes the a neurological phenomenon commonly observed in motor control and pivotal in maintaining appropriate muscle tension, involves a specific neuronal pathway with interneuronal processing between sensory and motor neurons, regulating muscle contraction by modulating motor neuron activity based on Golgi tendon organ input."

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs when IA spindle afferents are inhibited.

options.label: B
options.text: Is a monosynaptic reflex initiated by activation of the Golgi tendon organ.

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: C. Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Laboratory evaluation reveals a blood glucose level of 450 mg/dL, a serum bicarbonate level of 12 mmol/L, and an anion gap of 20. The patient is diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis DKA and started on intravenous insulin therapy. A few hours later, the patient begins to experience muscle weakness and a repeat laboratory test reveals a serum potassium level of 2.8 mmol/L . What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s hypokalemia?

options.label: B
options.text: Intracellular potassium shift due to insulin therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Gastrointestinal potassium loss due to vomiting

questions.correct_answer: B. Intracellular potassium shift due to insulin therapy
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Intracellular potassium shift due to insulin therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Metabolic alkalosis , aldosterone and angiotensin II
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Metabolic alkalosis , aldosterone and angiotensin II

questions.text: Physiologists divided the nerve fibers into specific groups based on the myelination and thickness of nerve fibers. Select the incorrect characteristic of nerve fibers in different groups:

options.label: A
options.text: Type C fibers are small unmyelinated nerve fibers that conduct impulses at low velocities.

options.label: B
options.text: Type A fibers are the typically large and medium-sized myelinated fibers of spinal nerves.

options.label: C
options.text: Type B fibers are further subdivided into α, β, and δ fibers.

options.label: D
options.text: Subset of type A fibers has conduction velocity between 70-120 m/s.

questions.correct_answer: C. Type B fibers are further subdivided into α, β, and δ fibers.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Type B fibers are further subdivided into α, β, and δ fibers.

questions.text: A medical student have given a topic to present in class. The topic given to you was excitation-contraction coupling. It is a process in which muscle cells are stimulated to contract and it is followed by muscle cell relaxation. It involves the following events. 1. Action potential 2. Calcium release into the cytoplasm 3. Cross-bridge cycling 4. Cytoplasmic calcium removal 5. Depolarization of T tubules Which of the following options lists the correct sequence of events for excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle tissue?
All of the following are components responsible for the counter current mechanism in the kidney except

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb

options.label: B
options.text: Water outflow in thin descending limb

options.label: C
options.text: Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb

options.label: D
options.text: Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.correct_answer: D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.text: A guinea-pig is dissected and a portion of its intestine is fixed in the modified Dales chamber to study the effects of some drugs on intestinal contractility. A substance X was infused in the broth following which the graph comes out as depicted. Substance X most closely resembles which of these substances?

A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden dizziness, nausea, and a drop in blood pressure after receiving an injection for a certain medical condition. On examination, his heart rate is found to be significantly lower than usual, leading towards the Bezold-Jarisch reflex. Which of the following is responsible for this condition?

A medical student is studying thyroid physiology and comes across the term 'Wolf-Chaikoff effect.' She is curious about the mechanism underlying this phenomenon. Which of the following best explains the Wolf-Chaikoff effect?
